Wonky Sprout OS

COMMAND CENTER SETUP SOP (CCS-SOP)

Date Created: 2025-11-09
Purpose: Define the complete equipment, software, and spatial requirements for the neurodivergent-optimized Command Center. Every choice matters. This is top priority.

Philosophy: The Command Center is the physical and digital foundation for all Solo Execution Mode work. It must eliminate friction, reduce cognitive load, and maximize focus capacity. This is not optional equipment‚Äîthis is the infrastructure that makes everything else possible.

1.0 SPACE REQUIREMENTS

1.1 Minimum Physical Footprint

  • Desk Surface: 60‚Äù √ó 30‚Äù minimum (5 sq ft)
  • Clearance: 36‚Äù behind chair for movement
  • Height: Adjustable 28‚Äù-48‚Äù (standing desk capability)
  • Total Floor Space: ~25 sq ft minimum

Why This Matters:

  • Autism/ADHD require reduced sensory overwhelm
  • Fixed spatial boundaries create predictability
  • Standing capability prevents hyperfocus-induced physical strain
  • Room to move = executive function preservation

1.2 Optimal Configuration

  • Desk Surface: 72‚Äù √ó 30‚Äù (6 sq ft) - allows dual monitor setup + physical notebook space
  • Dedicated Room: 10‚Äô √ó 10‚Äô (100 sq ft) with door for isolation
  • Window Access: Natural light + ability to cover for glare control
  • Climate Control: Independent thermostat or space heater/fan

Why Optimal Matters:

  • Door = hard boundary for Family Structure Mode transitions
  • Window = circadian rhythm regulation (critical for sleep anchor protocol)
  • Climate control = sensory regulation (temperature sensitivity common in ASD)

2.0 HARDWARE: TIER SYSTEM

TIER 1: MUST HAVES (Non-Negotiable)

2.1 Primary Computing

Desktop PC or High-Performance Laptop

  • Minimum Specs:
    • CPU: Intel i5 11th gen or AMD Ryzen 5 5600 equivalent
    • RAM: 16GB DDR4
    • Storage: 512GB NVMe SSD
    • GPU: Integrated graphics acceptable
  • Rationale:
    • VS Code + Chrome + NotebookLM + Jekyll dev server simultaneously
    • Multiple browser tabs for research (ADHD info gathering patterns)
    • Fast boot times reduce transition friction
    • SSD = instant file access (reduces waiting-induced context switching)

Budget: $600-$800 (refurbished Dell Optiplex or custom build)

Where to Buy (Per Attached Guide):

  1. Costco (best return policy + price)
  2. Amazon (Prime shipping + reviews)
  3. Craigslist/eBay (search guides: refurbished business-class machines)

2.2 Display System

Single 27‚Äù Monitor OR Laptop + 24‚Äù External

  • Minimum Specs:
    • Resolution: 1920√ó1080 (1080p)
    • Panel: IPS (color accuracy + viewing angles)
    • Inputs: HDMI + DisplayPort
    • VESA mount compatible
  • Rationale:
    • Reduces neck strain (ergonomics)
    • Sufficient real estate for side-by-side windows (documentation + code)
    • IPS = no color shift when standing vs sitting
    • VESA = adjustable height (critical for standing desk use)

Budget: $150-$250

Alternative: Dual 24‚Äù monitors ($300 total) for enhanced multitasking

2.3 Input Devices

Keyboard: Mechanical or High-Quality Membrane

  • Must Have: Full-size with numpad
  • Preference: Tactile feedback (satisfies sensory seeking)
  • Budget: $50-$100
  • Recommendations: Keychron C1, Logitech K840

Mouse: Wired or Wireless Ergonomic

  • Must Have: At least 2 programmable buttons
  • Preference: Vertical or angled (reduces wrist strain)
  • Budget: $25-$60
  • Recommendations: Logitech MX Master 3, Anker Vertical Mouse

Rationale:

  • Tactile keyboard feedback = ADHD dopamine micro-hits during typing
  • Ergonomic mouse = prevents RSI during hyperfocus marathons
  • Wired option = zero input lag (critical for flow state maintenance)

2.4 Audio System (The Bubble Shield)

Soundcore Space One Headphones (Already Owned ‚úÖ)

  • Profile 1.0: Deep Work (Transparency 3, Vol 20%)
  • Profile 2.0: Situational Awareness (Transparency 5, Vol 10%)
  • Backup: Wired earbuds (for battery failures)

Budget for Backup: $15-$30

2.5 Power Infrastructure

Surge Protector with 8+ Outlets

  • Must Have: 2000+ joule rating
  • Must Have: USB charging ports (2+ ports)
  • Budget: $25-$40
  • Recommendation: Belkin or Tripp Lite (Costco pricing)

UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply) - OPTIONAL but RECOMMENDED

  • Capacity: 600VA minimum (10-15 min runtime)
  • Budget: $80-$120
  • Rationale: Prevents work loss during power flickers (executive dysfunction amplifier)

2.6 Connectivity

Ethernet Cable (If Possible)

  • Length: 25-50 ft
  • Category: Cat6 minimum
  • Budget: $15-$25
  • Rationale: Wired = no Wi-Fi dropout during critical work blocks

Wi-Fi 6 USB Adapter (If Ethernet Impossible)

  • Budget: $25-$40

TIER 2: ESSENTIALS (Highly Recommended)

2.7 Ergonomics

Standing Desk Converter OR Full Standing Desk

  • Converter: $150-$300 (Vivo, FlexiSpot)
  • Full Desk: $300-$600 (autonomous.ai, Fully Jarvis)
  • Rationale: Sitting 7+ hours = physical toll + executive function degradation

Ergonomic Chair

  • Minimum: Lumbar support, adjustable height, armrests
  • Budget: $150-$300 (used Herman Miller on Craigslist, or Dexley from Staples)
  • Rationale: Physical discomfort = cognitive load = focus loss

Anti-Fatigue Mat (for Standing)

  • Budget: $30-$60
  • Rationale: Reduces foot fatigue during standing blocks

2.8 Lighting

Desk Lamp with Adjustable Brightness

  • Must Have: 3 brightness levels minimum
  • Must Have: Adjustable arm
  • Budget: $40-$80
  • Rationale: Overhead lighting causes glare + sensory overwhelm

Bias Lighting for Monitor

  • Budget: $15-$25 (USB LED strip)
  • Rationale: Reduces eye strain during evening work blocks

2.9 Cable Management

Cable Tray/Raceway System

  • Budget: $25-$50
  • Rationale: Visual clutter = cognitive load (ASD pattern recognition overwhelm)

Velcro Cable Ties

  • Budget: $10-$15

2.10 Secondary Input

Drawing Tablet or iPad (for Diagrams)

  • Budget: $50-$150 (Wacom Intuos, used iPad)
  • Rationale: Visual thinking tool for systems mapping (autistic strength)

TIER 3: OPTIMIZATION (Nice to Have)

2.11 Environmental Control

White Noise Machine

  • Budget: $40-$80
  • Rationale: Backup for headphone failures, masks unpredictable household noise

Air Purifier with HEPA Filter

  • Budget: $100-$200
  • Rationale: Reduces allergen-induced brain fog (maintains focus capacity)

Smart Bulbs (Philips Hue or Similar)

  • Budget: $50-$100
  • Rationale: Automated circadian lighting (supports sleep anchor protocol)

2.12 Productivity Tools

Stream Deck or Macro Pad

  • Budget: $80-$150
  • Rationale: One-button shortcuts reduce decision fatigue

Webcam + Microphone (for Content Creation)

  • Budget: $100-$200
  • Rationale: M1 (Media) module expansion capability

2.13 Physical Organization

Desktop Organizer System

  • Budget: $30-$60
  • Rationale: Fixed homes for tools (reduces search time = executive function tax)

Whiteboard (24‚Äù √ó 36‚Äù minimum)

  • Budget: $25-$50
  • Rationale: Externalized working memory (ADHD compensation strategy)

3.0 SOFTWARE STACK

3.1 Operating System

Windows 11 Pro (Current Setup ‚úÖ)

  • Rationale: Native PowerShell, VS Code optimization, Google Workspace integration
  • Alternative: Linux (if open-source philosophy matters more than convenience)

3.2 Core Development Environment

Visual Studio Code (Already Installed ‚úÖ)

  • Extensions Required:
    • GitHub Copilot (AI pair programming)
    • Markdown All in One (for SOP writing)
    • Live Server (for Jekyll preview)
    • GitLens (for commit history visualization)
    • Prettier (code formatting automation)

Git for Windows (Already Installed ‚úÖ)

  • Configuration: SSH keys for GitHub authentication

Ruby + Jekyll (For GitHub Pages Development)

  • Installation: Via RubyInstaller for Windows
  • Rationale: Local site preview before deployment

3.3 Google Workspace Integration (CRITICAL)

Google Chrome (Primary Browser)

  • Extensions:
    • Google Keep (quick capture sidebar)
    • Google Tasks (task list sidebar)
    • Dark Reader (reduces eye strain)
    • uBlock Origin (eliminates distraction/ads)

Google Drive for Desktop

  • Sync Folders:
    • ~/Documents/WonkySprout_Assets
    • ~/Documents/NotebookLM_Archive
  • Rationale: Automatic cloud backup (prevents catastrophic data loss)

Google Keep (Chaos Capture - Temporary)

  • Use Case: Voice-to-text quick captures during non-typing moments
  • Protocol: Daily dump to NotebookLM (see Foundational Daily Protocols)

Google Tasks (Daily Planning)

  • Integration: Chrome sidebar + mobile app
  • Protocol: 3 critical tasks identified each morning (see Solo Execution Mode)

Google Calendar (Scheduling)

  • Integration: Desktop notifications for time blocks
  • Protocol: Solo/Family mode transitions scheduled as recurring events

NotebookLM (Permanent Filing)

  • Use Case: Long-term knowledge base, SOP repository analysis
  • Protocol: Weekly upload of completed SOPs, blog drafts, system documentation

3.4 Communication (Minimal by Design)

Slack/Discord (Async Only)

  • Configuration: Notifications OFF except @mentions
  • Rationale: Protects focus during Solo Execution Mode

Email (Batch Processing)

  • Schedule: Check 2√ó daily maximum (11 AM, 4 PM)
  • Tool: Gmail web interface (no desktop client = reduces distraction)

3.5 Utilities

PowerToys (Windows) (Already Installed ‚úÖ)

  • Features Used: FancyZones (window snapping), PowerToys Run (launcher)

Everything Search (File Finder)

  • Budget: Free
  • Rationale: Instant file location (reduces ADHD ‚Äúwhere did I save that‚Äù frustration)

Greenshot (Screenshot Tool)

  • Budget: Free
  • Rationale: Quick visual capture for documentation

7-Zip (File Compression)

  • Budget: Free

4.0 GOOGLE WORKSPACE PROTOCOLS

4.1 File Organization Structure

Google Drive/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ WonkySprout_OS/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Active_Projects/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SOPs_Working/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Media_Assets/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Client_Work/ (Module 3)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ NotebookLM_Archive/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2025-11/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2025-10/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ [monthly folders]
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Personal/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Medical/
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Finance/

4.2 Daily Workflow Integration

  1. Morning (6:03 AM): Open Google Tasks in Chrome sidebar
  2. Core Work (8 AM-12 PM): VS Code + Chrome with Keep sidebar
  3. Capture Loop: Voice ‚Üí Keep ‚Üí Daily Dump ‚Üí NotebookLM
  4. Evening (5 PM): Review Calendar for next-day time blocks

4.3 Mobile Integration (Pixel Fold)

Apps Required:

  • Google Keep (sync with desktop)
  • Google Tasks (sync with desktop)
  • Google Drive (access to all files)
  • Gmail (email batch processing)
  • Chrome (bookmark sync)

Use Case: Chaos capture during Family Structure Mode (Fri 4 PM - Mon 6 PM)

5.0 SETUP PROCEDURE (DEPLOYMENT CHECKLIST)

Phase 1: Physical Space (2-4 hours)

  • Measure space and confirm minimum 60‚Äù √ó 30‚Äù desk footprint
  • Assemble desk (if new purchase)
  • Position desk near window (if available) with monitor perpendicular to window (glare control)
  • Install cable management tray under desk
  • Run ethernet cable to router (if possible)
  • Install surge protector under desk (accessible but hidden)
  • Set up chair and adjust height
  • Test standing desk converter (if applicable)

Phase 2: Hardware Installation (2-3 hours)

  • Unbox and connect monitor(s)
  • Connect keyboard and mouse
  • Install monitor arm or adjust stand height
  • Position desk lamp (avoid glare on monitor)
  • Install bias lighting behind monitor
  • Organize cables with velcro ties
  • Connect headphones charging station (USB port on surge protector)
  • Test all peripherals

Phase 3: Software Configuration (3-5 hours)

  • Install Windows updates
  • Install Google Drive for Desktop
  • Configure sync folders
  • Install VS Code + extensions
  • Install Git for Windows + configure SSH
  • Install Ruby + Jekyll
  • Install PowerToys + configure FancyZones
  • Install Everything Search
  • Install Greenshot
  • Install Chrome extensions (Keep, Tasks, Dark Reader, uBlock)
  • Configure Chrome sidebar (Keep + Tasks)
  • Log into Google Workspace (all services)
  • Test Jekyll local dev server (bundle exec jekyll serve)

Phase 4: Environment Calibration (1-2 hours)

  • Adjust monitor height (top of screen at eye level when seated)
  • Adjust desk lamp brightness (eliminate glare)
  • Test Bubble Shield Profile 1.0 (headphones)
  • Configure Windows focus assist (priority only during work blocks)
  • Set Chrome as default browser
  • Pin essential apps to taskbar: VS Code, Chrome, File Explorer
  • Create desktop shortcuts: Google Keep, Google Tasks, NotebookLM
  • Test standing desk transition (if applicable)

Phase 5: Protocol Integration Test (1 hour)

  • Run Morning Transition Protocol (MTP-SOP) at Command Center
  • Open VS Code and load WS-OS workspace
  • Open Chrome with Keep + Tasks sidebars
  • Test Pomodoro timer (25/5 intervals)
  • Execute Daily Dump Protocol (move Keep notes to NotebookLM)
  • Verify Google Calendar notifications appear
  • Test FancyZones window snapping

6.0 MAINTENANCE PROTOCOLS

Daily (During Foundational Daily Protocols)

  • Wipe down desk surface (5 min during tidying)
  • Organize cables if loose
  • Clear unnecessary items from desk

Weekly (During Weekly Review Protocol)

  • Archive completed Google Keep notes to NotebookLM
  • Review Google Drive storage usage
  • Update Windows (if pending)
  • Backup WS-OS local files to GitHub
  • Vacuum Command Center floor space

Monthly

  • Clean monitor and keyboard
  • Review cable management (retighten if needed)
  • Check headphone battery health
  • Update VS Code extensions
  • Audit Google Drive organization

7.0 BUDGET SUMMARY

Tier 1: Must Haves

GRAND TOTAL

  • Minimum (Tier 1): $865-$1,275
  • Recommended (Tier 1 + 2): $1,270-$2,080
  • Optimal (All Tiers): $1,560-$2,660

8.0 VALUE OPTIMIZATION (Per Attached Guide Principles)

Pre-Purchase Questions (For Every Item)

  1. Do we actually need it? Will this eliminate friction or just add complexity?
  2. What‚Äôs the ROI? How much focus capacity or time does this recover?
  3. Is this the right solution? Or is there a simpler non-monetary fix?
  4. What‚Äôs the failure cost? If this item breaks, what‚Äôs the productivity loss?

Buying Strategy

  1. Check Costco first (best return policy + pricing)
  2. Amazon Prime second (reviews + fast shipping)
  3. Craigslist/eBay for office surplus (business-class refurbs)
  4. Use 10% Lowes/Home Depot coupons (for desk/furniture)
  5. Search slickdeals.net (for planned purchases)
  6. Set CamelCamelCamel alerts (for non-urgent items)

Quality vs. Price Balance

  • Cheap = High Replacement Cost: Especially for keyboard/mouse (daily use items)
  • Expensive = Low Ongoing Cost: Chair and desk (prevents RSI, supports 7hr blocks)
  • ROI Calculation: If it saves 15 min/day setup time = 91 hrs/year = $2,730 value (at $30/hr rate)

9.0 TROUBLESHOOTING

Issue: Can‚Äôt Focus Even With Perfect Setup

Diagnosis: Command Center is necessary but not sufficient Fix: Review Foundational Daily Protocols (FDP-SOP) - likely sleep, hydration, or medication protocol failing

Issue: Physical Discomfort During Work Blocks

Diagnosis: Ergonomics failure Fix:

  1. Monitor at eye level (adjust stand or desk height)
  2. Chair lumbar support engaged
  3. Keyboard/mouse at elbow height
  4. Alternate sitting/standing every 90 min

Issue: Constant Distraction From Household Noise

Diagnosis: Bubble Shield insufficient OR door boundary violated Fix:

  1. Upgrade to Profile 1.0 (Transparency 3, Vol 20%)
  2. Add white noise machine as background layer
  3. Enforce Command Center door policy during Solo Execution Mode

Issue: Google Workspace Not Syncing

Diagnosis: Drive for Desktop configuration issue Fix:

  1. Check internet connection (ethernet preferred)
  2. Restart Google Drive app
  3. Verify sync folder paths
  4. Check storage quota (free up space if >90% full)

11.0 NOTES

Last Updated: 2025-11-09
Status: ACTIVE - Deployment in progress
Priority: TOP - Foundation for all Solo Execution Mode work

Key Principle: The Command Center is not about having the best gear. It‚Äôs about eliminating every friction point between your brain and your output. Every choice exists to reduce cognitive load, maintain focus capacity, and preserve executive function.

Anti-BS Check: If you find yourself spending 2 hours optimizing a $10 purchase, you‚Äôve violated the Value Optimization principle. Make the decision, execute, move on.

Wonky Sprout Philosophy: Structure and organization with a bit of chaos. The Command Center provides the structure. Your brain provides the chaos. Together, they build systems.
